journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Bioactive and Compatible Polymers

title-group.article-title: Chemical–physical and in vivo evaluations of a self-assembling amphiphilic peptide as an injectable hydrogel scaffold for biomedical applications

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry and Industrial Chemistry, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy
2Cardiovascular Research Laboratory, Cardiac, Thoracic and Vascular Department, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy
3Laboratory for Biomaterials and Graft Technology, Institute of Clinical Physiology, CNR, Massa, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Roberto Solaro, Department of Chemistry and Industrial Chemistry, University of Pisa, Via Risorgimento 35, 56126 Pisa, Italy. Email: rosola@dcci.unipi.it

abstract.p: The self-aggregation and gelation of an amphiphilic peptide (C17H35CONH–A4G3ERGD, peptide amphiphile) were studied by light scattering, viscometry, nuclear magnetic resonance diffusometry, and atomic force microscopy. The peptide amphiphile critical aggregation concentration was evaluated to be 16 and 60 µM by light scattering and viscometry, respectively. The observed difference was attributed to the larger sensitivity of the latter technique to the presence of long fibrils. The addition of one equivalent or more of divalent cations (Ca2+ and Mg2+) to peptide amphiphile formed dense incoherent hydrogels. Based on the atomic force microscopy and nanoindentation data, both the hydrogel morphology and stiffness were independent of the cation type and peptide amphiphile concentration. However, gel stiffness increased on increasing Ca2+/peptide amphiphile molar ratio while a parallel decrease in the apparent water diffusion rate was observed by nuclear magnetic resonance diffusometry. The dispersions of endothelial progenitor cells in the peptide amphiphile hydrogels were evaluated in vivo on a rat tissue hypoxia model. Significant capillary formation at the injection site was observed by tissue appearance and histological examination, which indicated endothelial progenitor cell/peptide amphiphile hydrogel-enhanced angiogenesis in ischemic tissue.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many hydrogel materials have been developed as delivery vehicles of bioactive molecules and cells in tissue engineering.1 –7 The injectable hydrogels, which gel under physiological conditions, hold great potential for bioapplications.8 –10 Cells and bioactive factors can be easily incorporated into a pregel and injected to the defect site. Both hard and soft tissues may be obtained depending on the hardening mechanism. In general, in situ cross-linking leads to stiff materials, whereas self-assembly provides flexible systems that are less toxic because of the lack of solvents and initiators.11

Self-assembly oligopeptides have been extensively investigated for protein folding12 –14 and as injectable scaffolds to support different cell types.4,6,15 –22 To obtain a better understanding of the mechanisms of peptide self-organization, we started an interdisciplinary study to explore the self-assembly of ionic oligopeptides,23 –26 their conformational dynamics27 and adsorption on inorganic supports.28

We investigated the self-aggregation and gelation of an amphiphilic peptide (C15H31CONH–A4G3ERGD, peptide amphiphile (PA)) as well as atomic force microscopy (AFM) morphological studies and mechanical analysis of PA hydrogels. These gels are currently being used for bone tissue repair.18,19,29 –31 A preliminarily evaluation of the therapeutic activity of endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) seeded in PA gels in a rat animal model of tissue hypoxia was carried out. Progenitor cells were used to release suitable growth factors and cytokines32 that would then recruit endothelial cells to initiate the formation of a blood vessel network.33 The use of hydrogel-embedded autologous EPCs represents an innovative approach to vascular regeneration. This study is the first quantitative correlation of the hydrogel chemical and rheological properties reported in the literature. Indeed, the EPC formulation combines the advantage of pharmacological and tissue therapies while avoiding practical, legal, and ethical issues connected with the use of embryonic stem cells.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All reactants were analytical grade. PA oligopeptide (C15H31CONH–A4G3ERGD, Molecular Weight [MW] 1169.33 g/mol) was purchased from Advanced ChemTech (Louisville, KY, USA) and stored at −18°C in sealed vials. All aqueous solutions were prepared using Milli-Q Advantage (Millipore, Bedford, MA) water. Muscovite mica dishes (9.5 mm diameter and 0.2 mm thickness) were acquired from Electron Microscopy Sciences (Fort Washington, PA, USA). Endothelial basal medium (EBM; EGM-2-MV SingleQuots), fetal bovine serum (FBS), and trypsin–ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) were purchased from Lonza (Walkersville, MD, USA). Lymphoprep was purchased from Nycomed (Oslo, Norway). Fibronectin was purchased from Calbiochem (Darmstadt, Germany). Tissue culture–disposable plastics were purchased from Greiner (Frickenhausen, Germany). Matrigel was purchased from BD Biosciences (San Jose, CA, USA). Duploject System syringe was obtained from Baxter (Deerfield, IL, USA). Athymic nude rats were purchased from Harlan (Udine, Italy).

sec.title: Instrumental characterizations
sec.p: The pH measurements were made using a combined glass microelectrode (Hamilton, Biotrode 238140/05) in connection with an automatic Radiometer Analytical TIM 900 (Radiometer Analytical SAS, Villeurbanne, France) pHmeter. A Perkin Elmer LS 50 (Perkin Elmer s.r.l., Monza, Italy) spectrofluorimeter equipped with a xenon pulsed lamp was used for light scattering measurements. The excitation wavelength was 320 nm. The scattered light was collected at 90° with respect to the excitation wavelength between 310 and 330 nm, using 10 × 2-mm quartz microcells (Helma GmbH & Co. KG, Müllheim, Germany). Viscosity measurements were performed at 25°C with an automated Micro Viscometer AMVn (Anton Paar GmbH, Graz, Austria) equipped with a 500 µL capillary. The results were expressed as specific viscosity (ηsp = (η/η0) − 1, where η and η0 are the viscosities of sample solution and solvent, respectively). The average size of PA aggregates was measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS; Delsa™Nano C; Beckman Coulter [Beckman Coulter Inc., Indianapolis, IN, USA]) taking the average of five measurements, which represented the hydrodynamic diameter of the particles. The zeta potential was estimated on the basis of electrophoretic mobility under an electric field as an average of 30 measurements. The temperature was kept constant at 25°C during size and zeta potential measurements. AFM topography scanning was performed in tapping modes using a Multimode AFM with Nanoscope IV controller (Veeco Metrology, Inc., Santa Barbara, CA, USA) equipped with E and J scanners. Measurements in fluid environment were performed using a MTFML cell (Veeco Metrology, Inc.) and NT-MDT probes (NT-MDT Co., Moscow, Russia) with elastic constant of 5 N/m and resonance frequency of 150 kHz. Samples imaged in air were scanned using RTESP probes (Veeco Instruments, Dourdan, France) with elastic constant of 40 N/m and resonance frequency of 300 kHz. Stiffness measurements were performed in liquid by the Multimode AFM equipped with PicoForce stage, allowing for closed-loop scans in the Z direction (J-type scanner), using a 10-µm borosilicate sphere mounted on a special cantilever with elastic constant of 4.5 N/m (Novascan Technologies, Inc., Ames, IA, USA). 1H–nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) diffusometry experiments were performed in the fringe field gradient of the 9.4 T Oxford superconducting magnet of Varian Infinity 400 (Agilent Technologies S.p.A., Cernusco s/n, Italy) instruments. The exact position corresponds to a proton resonance frequency of 100 MHz (located 308 mm below the isocenter) where the nominal field gradient strength in the vertical (z//B0) direction of the magnet is 42.5 T/m.34 The gradient strength was calibrated by measuring the translational self-diffusion coefficient of a standard water sample at different temperatures referring to the methodology reported by Mills.35 Samples were prepared by centrifugation of peptide/CaCl2 suspensions in 5-mm-diameter NMR tubes; the tubes were then inserted into the horizontal solenoid coil of a wide-line probe and kept at 37°C ± 0.1°C. The NMR 90° pulse width was set to 1.1 µs. Under this condition, the excited slice in the sample can be estimated to be about 1 mm along the gradient direction,36 a distance far greater than the average molecular displacement during the measurement. Diffusion coefficients along the gradient direction were measured by a Constant Time Stimulated Echo (CTSE) pulse sequence:37

where δ is the variable encoding time, and τ and Δ – τ are the constant time delays. It is worth mentioning that τ and (Δ – τ) correspond to τ 1 and τ 2 of Ref. 37, respectively, while δ has the same meaning as in Ref. 37. The different notations were adopted to emphasize that the echo decay depends upon the shift δ of the 180° pulse from the center of the constant τ interval; δ was chosen with the condition 0 < δ < τ.

Water self-diffusion coefficients along the field gradient direction were evaluated at different diffusion times Δ = 2, 10, and 100 ms, corresponding to different average displacements, with constant encoding time τ = 100 ms and variable encoding time δ ranging from 6 to 10 ms, from 6 to 38 ms, and from 6 to 60 ms, respectively, in order to obtain a good echo attenuation with a dynamic range of at least one order of magnitude for each Δ diffusion time.

sec.title: Hydrogel preparation
sec.p: Lyophilized PA powder was dissolved in Millipore Milli-Q water at specified concentrations (0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 mg/mL); the solution was then neutralized at pH 7.4 by dropwise addition of 0.01 N sodium hydroxide. Hydrogel formations were induced by the addition of the peptide solution to 0.2% CaCl2 solution in Ca/PA molar ratios of 0.2:1, 0.5:1, 2:1, 10:1, and 50:1 (Table 1). The resulting gel was vortexed, left standing for 30 minute, and then centrifuged at 10,000 r/minute for 10 minute.

caption.p: Evaluation of the hydrogels formed by addition of CaCl2 to 1 mL of PA solutions at pH 7.4.

fn.p: The data were averaged over five measurements.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: Human EPCs were obtained according to previously published methods.32 Briefly, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated from buffy coats of healthy blood donors by centrifugation through Lymphoprep density gradient. PBMCs (1 × 106/cm2) were seeded on fibronectin (Calbiochem, Darmstadt, Germany) and cultured in EBM-2 supplemented with EGM-2-MV SingleQuots and 5% FBS. Cells were cultured for 1 week to obtain EPC. EPC phenotype was confirmed by lectin staining and acetylated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) uptake and by endothelial marker expression.38 For the in vivo model injection, EPCs were detached by incubation with trypsin–EDTA and suspended (4 × 106 cells/mL) in EBM-2 containing 10 mM CaCl2.

sec.title: In vivo studies
sec.p: Three-month-old female athymic nude rats (n = 20) weighing about 300 g were used for dorsal subcutaneous injection (hypoxic model) and monitored over a period of 14 days. All the animals were caged under constant light and temperature conditions during experimentation and received humane care according to guidelines from the “Dipartimento Alimenti, Nutrizione e Sanità Pubblica Veterinaria – Ministero della Salute,” which approved this study based on Italian Legislative Decree 116/92 regarding animal experimentation. The rats were anesthetized with zoletil (40 mg/kg) and xylazine (5 mg/kg) before the implant, while enrofloxacina (Baytril® [Bayer HealthCare AG, Leverkusen, Germany] 2.5%) and meperidine (20–50 mg/kg) were administered as antibiotic and analgesic therapy, respectively. The animals were divided into five experimental groups (four animals for each group): control (vehicle injection), PA injection (1% w/v; Ca2+/PA = 0.5), EPC injection (1 × 106 cells), EPC/PA injection (1 × 106 cells in 1% w/v PA; Ca2+/PA = 0.5), and positive control (Matrigel). For each animal, two 500 µL subcutaneous injections were performed, using a Duploject System syringe.

sec.title: Histological analysis
sec.p: In each group, two animals were sacrificed and explanted after 7 days and 14 days. Photographs were taken for macroscopic observation of neovascularization. Both cutis and subcutis were carefully removed from the site of injection and fixed in 10% formalin for 20 h. All samples were processed through graded alcohol series and xylene, embedded in paraffin wax, and cut into 7-µm-thick cross sections. Sections were hematoxylin–eosin (H&E) stained. Angiogenesis induced at the injected site was assessed in terms of histological parameters. Photomicrographs of three cross sections from different animals were taken at different magnifications to histologically evaluate vascularization. Two blinded experienced investigators evaluated these histological findings.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The molecule of the investigated amphiphilic peptide (C15H31CONH–A4G3ERGD and PA) has three distinct regions (Figure 1): (1) a long hydrophobic alkyl tail, (2) a flexible linker composed of four alanine (A) and three glycine (G) residues, and (3) a hydrophilic head with the cell adhesion ligand RGD and a net negative charge. This PA structure was known to form long self-assembled fibrils in aqueous solutions.19

caption.p: Schematic representation of the amphiphilic peptide (PA).

sec.p: The critical aggregation concentration (CAC) for PA was evaluated by light scattering measurements on pH 7.4 oligopeptide water solutions between 6 and 300 µM. All measurements were taken at least 1.5 hour after solution preparation to allow completion of the self-assembly process.25 The scattered light increased considerably at concentrations above 20 µM (Figure 2), in agreement with 16 µM CAC.

caption.p: (a) Light scattering at 320 nm and (b) specific viscosity of pH 7.4 oligopeptide solutions.

sec.p: The CAC of PA was also determined by viscosity. A steep slope variation above 60 µM was observed in the plot of the specific viscosity versus oligopeptide concentration (Figure 2), which associated with oligopeptide aggregation. Indeed, solution viscosity should be more affected by the presence of long fibrils than by small aggregates. Accordingly, the larger value of the CAC measured by viscometry with respect to the light scattering data was associated with the need for the formation of long fibrils in solution.

The AFM topographic images of 10 mg/L (8.55 µM) peptide solutions deposited on mica did not show the presence of aggregates. However, sparse peptide fibrils (about 0.08–1.2 µm length, 80 nm width and 10 nm height) were detected in the case of 10 g/L (8.55 mM) peptide solutions analyzed immediately after solution preparation (Figure 3). A dense network of interwoven fibrils (~0.2–2 µm long, 80 nm wide, and 10 nm high) was detected 2 hours later (Figure 3). The absence of peptide aggregation below the CAC as well as the slowness of aggregation is supported by this value, although a significant contribution by aggregate sedimentation cannot be ruled out.

caption.p: (a) Sparse peptide fibrils (about 0.08–1.2 µm length, 80 nm width and 10 nm height) detected in the case of 10 g/L (8.55 mM) peptide solutions analyzed immediately after solution preparation. (b) A dense network of interwoven fibrils (~0.2–2 µm long, 80 nm wide, and 10 nm high) was detected 2 h later.

sec.p: The presence of small aggregates (39 nm average diameter) was observed by DLS on 0.1-mM PA solutions at pH 7.4 revealed. Approximately, 5% of ~140 nm and ~0.05% of ~1.3 µm aggregates were also detected. There was good agreement between the DLS data and the AFM observations. The zeta potential of the PA aggregates was −60.5 mV (c = 0.1 mM, pH 7.4, 25°C) as expected from the oligopeptide net negative charge.

sec.title: PA hydrogel formation and characterization
sec.p: The PA did not form stable hydrogels in water at pH 7.4 in the absence of added bivalent cations. The PA was composed of a hydrophobic domain with 16 carbon atoms, an A4G3 hydrophilic domain, a glutamic acid (E) residue, and a conical shape made of RGD. The E residue provided a net negative charge at pH 7.4; therefore, electrostatic repulsion helped prevent intermolecular aggregation that gave rise to gel formation. However, the addition of divalent cations could reduce charge repulsion by screening anionic residues and bridge PA molecules. In this case, due to hydrogen bonding, the hydrophobic interactions and ionic bridges influenced the molecular self-assembly to form a three-dimensional (3D) hydrogel network. Thus, an equivalent amount of either CaCl2 or MgCl2 in the solutions with 5, 10, and 20 g/L of PA gave rise to the formation of dense incoherent gels. No gel was formed in the presence of tenfold excess NaCl (Figure 4) due to the inability of monovalent cations to form effective ionic bridges between PA molecules.

caption.p: AFM topography of pH 7.4 water solutions containing 10 g/L PA after addition of a tenfold excess of (a) MgCl2 and (b) NaCl.
AFM: atomic force microscopy; PA: peptide amphiphile.

sec.p: Based on the potential of injectable hydrogels in regenerative medicine, the formation of PA/CaCl2 hydrogels by varying both the PA concentration (0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 mg/mL) and the CaCl2/PA molar ratio (0.2–50) was investigated. As expected, no appreciable hydrogel formation was detected when the Ca2+/PA molar ratio was 0.2. The network formation needed at least one calcium ion for every two PA molecules; thus, incoherent hydrogels were formed at Ca2+/PA molar ratios of ≥0.5.

To recover the gels, the suspensions were centrifuged at 10,000 r/minute and the supernatant removed. No significant topology differences of the surface morphology were observed by AFM analysis of the hydrogels with divalent cation (Ca2+ and Mg2+); PA concentration of 4.28, 8.55, and 17.1 mM; and Ca2+/PA molar ratios of 0.5, 2.0, 10, and 50 (Figure 5).

caption.p: AFM topography of centrifuged hydrogels prepared by addition of CaCl2 to 1% PA solution at (a) 0.5 and (b) 50 Ca2+/PA molar ratio.
AFM: atomic force microscopy; PA: peptide amphiphile.

sec.p: After lyophilization, the hydrogel dry weight corresponded to that calculated on the assumption that all the PA was included in the gel. On this basis, the gel swelling ratio (swollen gel weight/dry gel weight) was evaluated to be included between about 150 and 250, the lowest and highest values corresponding to the highest and lowest Ca2+/PA molar ratio, respectively. The amount of recovered hydrogel was basically independent of Ca2+/PA molar ratio (Figure 6) and was roughly proportional to PA concentration, at least within the limits of experimental errors (Table 1). These results indicate that one calcium ion for every two PA molecules sufficed for the formation of a 3D network.

caption.p: Dependence of the (a) hydrogel weight and (b) stiffness on the peptide content and CaCl2/oligopeptide molar ratio in 1 mL of water solution at pH 7.4.

sec.p: The stiffness of PA/CaCl2 hydrogels was investigated by AFM indentation.39,40 A 10 µm borosilicate sphere mounted on a special cantilever with 4.5 N/m elastic constant was used because of the incoherence and relative softness of the hydrogels. The hydrogel stiffness quickly increased to Ca2+/PA molar ratio of 2 (Figure 6) and then kept increased linearly with increasing Ca2+/PA molar ratio. The gel stiffness seemed to be independent of peptide concentration, although our data were not sufficient to draw a sound conclusion; the observed behavior may be attributable to a combination of two concurrent mechanisms: (1) the PA cross-linking is more effective, at least up to a Ca2+/PA molar ratio of 2/1 and (2) the ionic strength toughens the hydrogel.

sec.title: NMR diffusometry
sec.p: To evaluate the effect of peptide network on water diffusion, NMR diffusometry was used on two hydrogels at different diffusion times Δ, with respect to the PA sequence. The tested hydrogels involved CaCl2 with concentrated (HC; PA 0.2 mM) and diluted (LC; 7.0 µM) peptide solutions at Ca2+/PA molar ratio of 0.5. By choosing diffusion times Δ and encoding times τ smaller than the relaxation times, the echo decay can be expressed37 as a function of the variable delay δ (equation (1))
where
and

In this case, the Δ and τ were kept constant, and so the NMR relaxation did not affect the echo decay as δ increased and was dependent only on time delays, field gradient strength and the self-diffusion coefficient D along the gradient direction.

In principle, the diffusion coefficient of bulk water is independent of the diffusion time Δ. As the sample size (~1 mm) was several orders of magnitude larger than the average trajectories of water molecules,37 a Gaussian distribution of the Brownian displacements can be expressed as (Equation (2))

The water diffusion coefficient D was about 3 × 10−9 m2 s−1 at 37°C, and the diffusion time Δ was about 100 ms; hence, the inspected water molecule trajectories were much smaller than the NMR sample tube dimension. This is a case of the so-called free diffusion. However, in the presence of a microscopic network, as in the case for the peptide gel samples, the flow of water molecules is further restricted. Simply, water molecules can diffuse through a peptide network; this boundary condition makes the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) dependent on the diffusion time Δ.41 Accordingly, the diffusion coefficient should decrease as the diffusion time increases, and a further reduction expected on increasing the network density.

To test this behavior, water diffusion was measured at 37°C in bulk water and in two peptide gels at different concentrations and diffusion times. The water diffusion coefficients D were evaluated by fitting the experimental values to equation (1) (Figure 7). Based on the echo decays, the bulk water diffusion was constant within the experimental error whereas the water diffusion in the hydrogels decreased as the diffusion time Δ increased (Figure 7). The ADC decreased further as the hydrogel network became tighter, as shown in Figure 8, where different ADCs are compared at the same diffusion times.

caption.p: (a) Log–log plot of the 1H water signal echo decays versus δ at 37°C (10 ms diffusion time; lines represent the decay fitting according to equation (1)) and (b) log–log plot of water apparent diffusion coefficients (ADC) versus Δ – τ diffusion time at 37°C (lines are reported as eye guides).

Histological sections of rat subcutis (EPC-injected group) at 14 days are shown with the injection sites and the surrounding tissues. The sections were stained with hematoxylin–eosin. Representative images at different magnifications (10×–50×–100×–200×) are presented. Arrows indicate capillary presence.

sec.p: These results are consistent with disordered hydrogel network frame that hinders the water molecule trajectories through the hydrogel, thus forcing their paths to be more tortuous than in the case of bulk water. This also decreased the diffusion coefficient, measured by NMR, as it is related to the unidimensional projection along the field gradient direction of the 3D path covered by water molecules during the diffusion time Δ.37 A decrease in the ADCs would be more significant in the case of larger molecules such as proteins.42

sec.title: Animal studies
sec.p: The long-term goal of the present research is the development of an “injectable cell–scaffold based system” that revascularizes and regenerates ischemic tissue by transplantation of EPCs entrapped in the 3D matrix of a biodegradable hydrogel scaffold—thus reducing the fibrosis and the size of the necrotic area. Adult peripheral blood contains bone marrow–derived progenitor cells with properties similar to those of embryonic angioblasts. These precursor cells have been termed as EPCs. Recently, the effective contribution of EPC to neovascularization of ischemic lesions, mainly through paracrine release of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, was reported.32 We, therefore, carried out a preliminary investigation of the efficacy of EPC dispersions in the PA hydrogel in the regeneration of tissue hypoxia using 20 athymic nude rats as a model for hind limb ischemia. The animals were evenly divided into five groups and received a dorsal subcutaneous injection (hypoxic model) of vehicle (control), PA hydrogel (PA 1% w/v; Ca2+/PA = 0.5), EPC, EPC in PA hydrogel (1 × 106 cells in 1% w/v PA; Ca2+/PA = 0.5), and Matrigel (positive control). For each group, two animals were sacrificed and explanted after 7 and 14 days, and histology of their tissues was analyzed.

After 7 days, no significant histological differences were observed in any of the rat subcutis. However, after 14 days (Figure 8), both the tissue appearance and histology were significantly higher capillary formation at the injection site of the EPC/PA group compared to the control group and a comparable positive control (Figure 9). Since EPC affects the paracrine release of cytokines/chemokines,32 fibroblast growth factor was slowly released in mouse subcutis from PA hydrogels both in vitro and in vivo due to diffusion and PA degradation.19 It seems that the late capillary formation in the EPC/PA was due to the slow EPC release and to the sustained delivery of their inflammatory cytokines and chemokines from the injectable PA hydrogel, thus enhancing the angiogenesis. However, this hypothesis needs further investigation.

caption.p: (a) Tissue appearance (bar size of 1 mm) and (b) histological sections of rat subcutis, taken 14 days after subcutaneous injection of vehicle (Ctr), PA, EPC, and PA + EPC. Histological sections were stained with hematoxylin–eosin. Representative pictures at 200× magnifications are shown. Arrows indicate capillary presence.
Ctr: control; PA: peptide amphiphile; EPC: endothelial progenitor cell.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It is well known that PA solutions form dense incoherent hydrogels on addition of divalent cations. However, the use of AFM nanoindentation and NMR diffusometry, for the first time, provided quantitatively correlate gel stiffness and morphology data, and apparent water diffusion rate with cation/PA molar ratio. Moreover, investigation of PA self-aggregation by light scattering, viscometry, and AFM allowed the differentiation of the sensitivities of the adopted techniques to aggregate shape and length. Last but not least, preliminary in vivo animal tests well support the angiogenic potential of EPC dispersions in PA hydrogels.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This project was funded, in part, through a grant from Fondazione Cassa di Risparmio di Pisa (118/07 project) and also in part by a grant from Tuscany Region Health AOOGRT/102715/Q.20.70.20 project. INSTM co-financed post-doc grant (for M.A.).
